prompt: What tariffs has the US imposed on China since Jan 2025?

sample_results.state_act_title: United States of America: Reclassification of certain vehicles for transport of goods and consequent increase in MFN Duty

intervention_description.text:
On 21 January 2026, the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) issued a ruling relating to the tariff classification of certain vehicles for transport of goods (“micro truks”). With the ruling, CBP reclassified “micro truks” as vehicles for the transport of goods under HTSUS 8704.31.01 rather than as works trucks under HTSUS 8709.19.00. Consequently, the import tariff for certain vehicles for transport of goods (“micro truks”) increased from duty-free to 25%.
This ruling will become effective on 22 March 2026.

state_act_source.text: U.S. Customs and Border Protection (21 January 2026). Revocation of Two Ruling Letters and Revocation of Treatment Relating to the Tariff Classification of Certain Vehicles for Transport of Goods. CUSTOMS BULLETIN AND DECISIONS, VOL. 60, NO. 3.: https://www.cbp.gov/sites/default/files/2026-01/Vol%2060_No_3_Complete_0.pdf

prompt: Which countries have imposed tariffs affecting US exports in 2025?

sample_results.state_act_title: Mexico: Removal of several products from the "basic basket" products list temporarily exempted from import duties (December 2025)

intervention_description.text:
On 31 December 2025, the government of Mexico published a Decree increasing the import tariffs on 33 products classified under 31 six-digit tariff subheadings. The Decree removes these new products from the "basic basket" products list first established in May 2022 and its modifications (see related state acts). The measure will enter into force one day following its publication, namely on 1 January 2026.

Among the affected products are beef and pork (live animals and meat), milk and dairy products, paddy rice, dried beans and other legumes, vegetable oils (soybean, sunflower, safflower and cottonseed), tilapia, and sausages and similar meat products. According to the latest edition of the Law on General Import and Export Taxes (7 June 2022 and its modifications), the newly applicable MFN duties will range between 5% and 45%.

In addition, the Decree also extends the "basic basket" tariff exemptions until December 2026 (see related state acts).

sample_results.state_act_title: Brazil: Modification of import tariff-rate quotas and import duties for 15 products (December 2025)

intervention_description.text:
On 30 December 2025, Brazil's Executive Committee of the Foreign Trade Chamber (GECEX) issued Resolution No. 844, increasing the import tariff for products under NCM 4014.10.00 and 2836.20.10 from 0% to 9%. This measure enters into force on 1 January 2026.

The Decree also modified the import tariff-rate quotas for other products (see related intervention) and extended them for NCM 2106.90.90 Ex-tárifario N. 29 and NCM 7020.00.10 (see related state acts).

The change is made via a modification of Annexe V of GECEX Resolution No. 272 of November 2021. These products were previously included in Annexe V by Resolutions 818/2025 (see related state act) and 318/2022.

This Annexe corresponds to the latest version of the List of Exceptions to the Common External Tariff (LETEC). The prior duties were retrieved from Annexe I of GECEX Resolution No. 272 (the TEC tariffs).

List of Exceptions to the Common External Tariff

LETEC is a mechanism that allows member states of Mercosur to apply customs duties that are lower or higher than otherwise listed in the Mercosur Common External Tariff schedule. However, the tariffs shall not surpass the ceilings given by the WTO.

sample_results.state_act_title: Iraq: Government implements new customs tariffs on hybrid vehicles and gold starting from 1 January 2026

intervention_description.text:
On 30 December 2025, the General Authority of Customs of Iraq introduced new import tariffs on hybrid vehicles and gold. Specifically, according to several new reports, a 15% customs duty applies to imported hybrid cars. Before this reform, hybrid vehicles were exempt from customs duties, effectively resulting in a zero-duty rate. According to the Iraqi News Agency press release, the new measure introduces an ad valorem customs duty of 5% on gold, which did not previously apply.

The decision enters into effect on 1 January 2026.

prompt: What export controls has China imposed on rare earth elements?

sample_results.state_act_title: China: Government grants export license to Ningbo Jintian Copper

intervention_description.text:
On 10 December 2025, the Chinese company Ningbo Jintian Copper announced that it had been granted an export license for the export of rare earth permanent magnet products. The statement was made on the Shanghai Stock Exchange Interactive Platform.

According to the company's statement, its "rare earth permanent magnet products are widely used in various high-end fields such as new energy vehicles, wind power generation, high-efficiency energy-saving motors, robots, consumer electronics, and medical devices." The company "primarily engages in non-ferrous metal processing, with main products including copper products and rare earth permanent magnet materials." (unofficial translation)

Several other Chinese companies were also reportedly to have secured "general" export licenses to export rare-earth-related items days ago (see related state act).

Notably, the news was reported following the US-China trade and economic agreement announced in late October 2025. The White House's Fact Sheet on the deal noted that China would "issue general licenses" for the benefit of US end users. This was not confirmed by the Chinese government at the time of writing.

sample_results.state_act_title: China: Government grants rare earth export license to several Chinese companies

intervention_description.text:
On 2 December 2025, several news outlets reported that the Chinese government issued "general" export licenses allowing several Chinese companies to export rare-earth-related items. The companies reportedly include JL MAG Rare-Earth Co, Beijing Zhong Ke San Huan Hi-Tech Co, and Yunsheng Group. The news did not specify the specifics of the official implementation.

According to the reports, JL MAG Rare-Earth Co, Beijing Zhong Ke San Huan Hi-Tech Co, and Yunsheng Group received general export licences for rare-earth-related items under the Chinese government’s regulatory framework. In this context, He Yadong, spokesman for the MOFCOM, said, "The Chinese government conducts export controls on rare earth-related items in accordance with laws and regulations. To my knowledge, the Chinese government promptly approves all compliant export applications for civilian use. At the same time, the Chinese government actively applies facilitation measures such as general licensing to promote compliant trade in dual-use items and effectively safeguard the security and stability of the global supply chain." (unofficial translation)

The export licensing requirement for various items related to certain medium and heavy rare earths was announced by the Chinese government on 4 April 2025 (see related state act).

Notably, the news was reported following the US-China trade and economic agreement announced in late October 2025. The White House's Fact Sheet on the deal noted that China would "issue general licenses" for the benefit of US end users. This was not confirmed by the Chinese government at the time of writing.

sample_results.state_act_title: China: Temporary suspension of additional export controls for rare earth-related technologies and  foreign entities that export Chinese-origin rare-earth materials

intervention_description.text:
On 7 November 2025, the Chinese Ministry of Commerce adopted Announcement 2025/70, temporarily suspending export control measures on rare-earth–related technologies, effective immediately until 10 November 2026.

As part of the suspension, the export licensing requirements for the following items are suspended:

  • technologies for rare-earth mining, smelting and separation, metal refining, magnet manufacturing, and recycling of secondary rare-earth resources;
  • technical know-how used to assemble, start up, maintain, repair, or upgrade rare-earth production lines;
  • other goods, technologies, and services if the exporter knows they will be used for overseas rare-earth mining, separation, metal refining, magnet making, or recycling.

The export control measures were initially announced on 9 October 2025 via Announcement 2025/62 (see related state act). The current Announcement 70 suspends all export controls announced that had been announced by the Ministry on 9 October 2025 (see related interventions and state acts).

The suspension implements commitments made by the Chinese government as part of the trade and economic agreement reached with the US in October 2025 (see related state act).

prompt: Which countries have restricted exports of lithium or cobalt since 2022?

sample_results.state_act_title: China: Cancellation and reduction of export tax rebates for photovoltaic products and batteries

intervention_description.text:
On 8 January 2026, the Chinese Ministry of Finance and the State Administration of Taxation adopted Announcement 2026/2, announcing the reduction of value-added tax rebates for battery-related products, such as lithium-ion batteries, from 9% to 6%. This includes 22 HS codes at the 8-digit or 10-digit level in Chapter 85. The reduction takes effect from 1 April 2026 and will remain in effect until 31 December 2026.

Within the same document, the government announced additional measures to cancel the export tax rebate for photovoltaic products and batteries (see related interventions).

In November 2024, the government removed various products from the list of goods eligible for export rebates (see related state act).

On 20 January 2026, the government spokesman replied to Bloomberg's question regarding this measure and noted, "This adjustment to the export tax rebate policy will help promote the efficient use of resources, reduce environmental pollution and carbon emissions, and drive a comprehensive green transformation of economic and social development. At the same time, it will also help guide the rational adjustment of industrial structure, promote industrial transformation and upgrading, comprehensively address 'involutionary' competition, and promote high-quality economic development." (unofficial translation)

prompt: What measures currently affect semiconductor manufacturing equipment trade?

sample_results.state_act_title: United States of America (Texas): USD 14.1 million grant to Coherent Corp under Texas Semiconductor Innovation Fund

intervention_description.text:
On 6 February 2026, the government of the state of Texas announced a USD 14.1 million grant to Coherent Corp through the Texas Semiconductor Innovation Fund. The funding supports the production of Indium Phosphide (InP) wafers at the company's facility in Sherman, Texas.

According to the press release, the project involves a total capital investment of more than USD 154 million to produce technology used for data communications, telecommunications, artificial intelligence interconnects, and satellite communications.

In this context, Texas's Governor Greg Abbott said: “Texas is the new frontier for technological innovation. This $154 million investment by Coherent to establish the world’s first 6-inch InP wafer fabrication plant in Sherman is testament to Texas’ leadership in semiconductor manufacturing and the technologies of tomorrow. With our skilled and growing workforce and the best business climate in the nation, Texas is where the future is building.”

Texas Semiconductor Innovation Fund (TSIF)

The grant program was launched in 2023 under the Texas CHIPS Act (see related state act). The scheme aims to support Texas’s leadership in semiconductor research, design, and manufacturing.

state_act_source.text: Office of the Texas Governor (6 February 2026). Governor Abbott Announces Texas Semiconductor Innovation Fund Grant to Coherent. Press release (10 February 2026): https://gov.texas.gov/news/post/governor-abbott-announces-texas-semiconductor-innovation-fund-grant-to-coherent

sample_results.state_act_title: China: Government reportedly allows several Chinese firms to import of Nvidia H200 AI chips

intervention_description.text:
On 28 January 2026, several news outlets reported that the Chinese government authorised the purchase of more than 400'000 Nvidia H200 artificial intelligence chips by ByteDance, Alibaba, and Tencent. Previously, it had been reported that the Chinese government restricted Chinese tech companies from purchasing Nvidia's H200 chips (see related state act).

According to Reuters, the approval will be subject to certain conditions currently being determined by the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology and the Ministry of Commerce. These conditions may include a requirement for companies to purchase a specific ratio of domestic semiconductors alongside foreign chips. It is reported that other Chinese firms are currently in a queue for subsequent import approvals.

On 22 January 2026, the Export-Import Bank of Korea announced that it would provide KRW 20 trillion (USD 13.6 billion) in, among others, loans to entities in the AI industry. sample_results.state_act_title: United States of America: EXIM approves loan to establish a Strategic Critical Minerals Reserve

intervention_description.text:
On 2 February 2026, the US government, through the Export-Import Bank of the United States, approved a Direct Loan of up to USD 10 billion to support Project Vault in the United States. The financing aims to establish a Strategic Critical Minerals Reserve to secure access to essential raw materials for domestic manufacturers. The intervention targets US-based manufacturing supply chains and seeks to support production, processing, and storage of critical minerals across multiple states.

The approved loan will provide long-term financing to Project Vault, an independently governed public-private partnership involving original equipment manufacturers and private capital providers. According to the announcement, participating manufacturers reportedly include Clarios, GE Vernova, Western Digital, and Boeing, while suppliers include Hartree Partners, Mercuria Americas, and Traxys. The reserve is expected to store critical raw materials in facilities distributed across the United States to mitigate supply disruptions.

In this context, EXIM Chairman John Jovanovic said: “Project Vault is designed to support domestic manufacturers from supply shocks, support U.S. production and processing of critical raw materials, and strength America’s critical minerals sector. Thanks to President Trump’s leadership, the U.S. Strategic Critical Minerals Reserve will help manufacturers in the United States compete, grow, and lead globally while creating jobs domestically, strengthening our economy, and advancing the national interest.”

On 28 January 2026, the UK National Wealth Fund (NWF) released a strategic plan outlining its intent to commit its remaining GBP 19.4 billion (USD 26.8 billion) in capital by 2030/31. The plan identified 25 target sectors* across clean energy, infrastructure, and advanced industries. The announcement did not specify the intervention types or financial instruments through which support would be delivered.

The strategic plan identified three targets: accelerating decarbonisation, enabling place-based investment across all UK nations, and strengthening sovereign capabilities in critical supply chains. The NWF stated that its support is expected to create or sustain more than 200'000 jobs and help avoid 500 million tonnes of CO2e emissions by 2050.

In this context, Energy Secretary Ed Miliband said: "Clean energy is not just about energy sovereignty, it is about bringing back the good industrial jobs that have been denied to our country for too long. Thanks to the certainty of the government's clean energy superpower mission and public investment like this - the industry is responding with record investment- meaning better jobs for people across our country."

sample_results.state_act_title: Canada: New measures to support the automobile industry

intervention_description.text:
On 5 February 2026, the Canadian government announced it would allocate of CAD 3 (USD 2.22) billion from the Strategic Response Fund to support the local automotive industry. The government did not specify the form the support would take.

According to the press release, the measures aim to assist the sector in adapting and diversifying into new international markets. This funding is part of a broader industrial strategy to reduce reliance on one trade partner and increase economic resilience. The government also confirmed the maintenance of counter-tariffs on automotive imports from the United States to ensure a level playing field for domestic manufacturers.

The Strategic Response Fund (SRF) replaces the Strategic Innovation Fund (SIF), building on its mandate, and is a federal program that supports Canada's industrial transformation by investing in sectors vulnerable to trade disruptions, including automotive, steel, and aluminium.

In the same announcement, the government committed up to CAD 100 (USD 73.88) million from the Regional Tariff Response Initiative to support the automotive industry. This scheme did not pass the GTA reporting criteria, as only small and medium-sized enterprises are eligible for funding.

In this context, Mark Carney, Prime Minister of Canada, said: “Canada’s new government is fundamentally transforming our economy – from one reliant on a single trade partner, to one that is stronger, more independent, and more resilient to global shocks. We are making strategic decisions and generational investments to build a strong Canadian auto sector, where Canadian workers build the cars of the future".

sample_results.state_act_title: Canada: New measures to support the automobile industry

intervention_description.text:
On 5 February 2026, the Canadian government announced it would launch a 5-year Electric Vehicle (EV) Affordability Programme with a budget of CAD 2.3 (USD 1.7) billion. The initiative provides purchase or lease incentives of up to CAD 5'000 (USD 3'694) for battery electric and fuel cell vehicles and up to CAD 2'500 (USD 1'847) for plug-in hybrids. A price cap of CAD 50'000 (USD 36'942) applies to vehicles manufactured in countries with which Canada has free trade agreements; however, Canadian-made electric vehicles are exempt from this cap.

This differential treatment effectively extends the subsidy to a wider range of Canadian-produced vehicles — including higher-priced models — while excluding comparable foreign-made EVs from the same benefit, thereby conferring a competitive advantage on domestic producers.

In this context, Mark Carney, Prime Minister of Canada, said: “Canada’s new government is fundamentally transforming our economy – from one reliant on a single trade partner, to one that is stronger, more independent, and more resilient to global shocks. We are making strategic decisions and generational investments to build a strong Canadian auto sector, where Canadian workers build the cars of the future".

The loan will support the equipment of seven manufacturing plants within a new industrial cluster for automotive components and electric vehicles in the Kaliningrad region.

The seven production facilities cover seats, exhaust systems, traction electric motors, electronic control systems (including ERA-GLONASS devices), plastic automotive parts, compact electric vehicles, and tooling/equipment for automotive component production. According to the press release, the cluster is designed to increase localisation levels, with up to 80% of components planned to be produced within Kaliningrad Oblast, and incorporates advanced automation, robotics, and elements of artificial intelligence.

The precise date when the loan was issued was not disclosed. Following a conservative approach, the date of the IDF news release was selected as an inception date.

sample_results.state_act_title: EU: Action plan on drone and counter-drone security to support the development of homegrown technologies

intervention_description.text:
On 11 February 2026, the European Commission published an Action Plan on Drone and Counter-Drone Security to support the prevention, detection, and response to malicious drone activities. Among other actions the communication signals the EU's intention to support the development of homegrown technologies through state aid.

More concretely, the Action Plan emphasises accelerating the expansion and industrial scaling of EU-based drone and counter-drone companies, as well as increasing manufacturing capacity, by:

  • identifying strategic investment priorities that favour innovative, scalable solutions developed by emerging actors operating across both civilian and defence sectors;
  • coordinating and activating sufficient public and private financing at both national and EU levels, spanning civilian and military domains;
  • drawing on cohesion policy resources and encouraging complementary national funding to prevent duplication, streamline financial flows, and concentrate support on clearly defined strategic priorities.

Most of the funding for the goals of the Action Plan will come from already existing programmes, such as the European Defence Fund (EDF), the European Defence Industry Programme (EDIP), the SAFE instrument (Security Action for Europe), the European Innovation Council (EIC), the EU Disruptive Innovation Scheme (EUDIS), the Border Management and Visa Instrument (BMVI). In the medium term, the defence, resilience and security window of the forthcoming European Competitiveness Fund (ECF) will also support the goals of this Action Plan.

In this context, Commissioner for Defence and Space, Andrius Kubilius, noted, "With the launch of this Action Plan, we are turning the concept of a ‘Drone Wall’ from a political vision into an industrial reality. To achieve true defence readiness, Europe must be able to protect its borders and critical sites with a sophisticated, multi-layered shield that can detect and neutralise any threat in real-time. Commission is developing a range of tools to the industry and Member States to develop and acquire drone and anti-drone defence capabilities in Europe. This includes the Eastern Flank Watch initiative and European Drone Defence Initiative. By bridging the gap between innovative civilian technology and military requirements, we are ensuring that our defence industry can produce these essential systems at the scale and speed required to keep Europe secure and technologically sovereign.'

https://digital-strategy.ec.europa.eu/en/library/action-plan-drone-and-counter-drone-security

sample_results.state_act_title: Italy: EUR 390 million rescue loan to Acciaierie d'Italia

intervention_description.text:
On 9 February 2026, the European Commission approved a EUR 390 million (USD 463.5 million) rescue loan from Italy. The measure will support Acciaierie d'Italia (AdI) to meet its liquidity needs and cover standard operating costs such as wages and supplier payments. AdI is an Italian integrated steel producer with eight different production and servicing sites.

Specifically, the funding addresses the company's projected liquidity shortfall and ensures the continuity of its operations during an ongoing insolvency process that began in 2024 (see related state acts). This support is intended to bridge the financial gap until the business is transferred to a new operator following a tender process. The loan is granted at market rates for a duration of six months, after which Italy must submit a restructuring or liquidation plan or demonstrate that the loan has been repaid.

The Commission approved the rescue loan after assessing it under Article 107(3)(c) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU).

As of February 2026, the European Commission has not published its decision.

sample_results.state_act_title: Germany: EUR 3 billion state aid scheme for cleantech manufacturing capacity

intervention_description.text:
On 5 February 2026, the European Commission approved a EUR 3 billion (USD 3.5 billion) state aid scheme from Germany. The measure will support investments that add manufacturing capacity for net-zero technologies and their components. The aid will take the form, among others, of direct grants. The scheme will be valid until 31 December 2030.

Specifically, eligible investment include net-zero technologies and their main specific components listed in Annexe II of the CISAF, secondary raw materials and the production of new or recovered related critical raw materials necessary for the production of those final products or main specific components. Some examples of eligible products are batteries, solar panels, wind turbines, heat-pumps, electrolysers, and carbon capture, usage and storage, including main specific components. The aid will also take the form of interest subsidies for loans, guarantees and tax advantages (see related interventions).

In this context, Teresa Ribera, Executive Vice-President for Clean, Just and Competitive Transition, said: "This scheme will ensure additional clean technology manufacturing capacity in Germany. The German state can provide EUR 3 billion in support for key investments in the sector".

As of February 2026, the European Commission has not published its decision.

The state aid is approved under the Clean Industrial Deal state aid framework (CISAF) of June 2025. The framework allows Member States to provide financial support for the development of clean energy and technology, as well as industrial decarbonisation (see related state act).

Moreover, this is the first project contracted under the Public Call for Selection of Business Plans for Investments in the Transformation of Strategic Minerals for Energy Transition and Decarbonization - Joint BNDES-Finep Promotion Action (see related state act).

In this context, the BNDES President, Aloizio Mercadante, noted: "This project has strategic importance for Brazil. It is another step in the decarbonisation agenda, contributing to strengthening energy security, increasing the resilience of the electricity grid, and expanding renewable energy sources. Under the guidance of President Lula, Brazil is building a new cycle of development, with innovation and sustainability" (own translation).

prompt: What safeguard measures are currently in force on solar panels?

sample_results.state_act_title: United States of America: Safeguard measure on imports large residential washing machines

intervention_description.text:
On January 22, 2018, U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer announced that President Trump has approved recommendations to impose safeguard tariffs on imported residential washing machines (as well as solar cells and modules), based on the investigations, findings, and recommendations of the U.S. International Trade Commission (USITC). The restrictions will be imposed for three years on the following schedule:

Tariff-Rate Quotas on Washers
Year 1:
20% on the first 1.2 million units of imported finished washers; 50% on all subsequent imports of finished washers; 50% tariff on covered parts after the first 50,000 units 

Year 2:
18% on the first 1.2 million units of imported finished washers; 45% on all subsequent imports of finished washers; 45% tariff on covered parts after the first 70,000 units 

Year 3:
16% on the first 1.2 million units of imported finished washers; 40% on all subsequent imports of finished washers; 40% tariff on covered parts after the first 90,000 units 

The restrictions came into effect on February 7, 2018.

Together with the solar cells and modules case, this is the first time that the United States has resorted to the global safeguard since invoking that "escape clause" in a 2001 steel case. The restrictions imposed then, like nearly all other uses of the safeguard by all countries since the World Trade Organization came into existence in 1995, was found in a WTO dispute-settlement panel to have violated the terms of the WTO Agreement on Safeguards. It is widely expected that this latest case will lead to a similar challenge. If that challenge is successful (as is widely expected), the United States will need to decide if it will comply with its WTO obligations by bringing these restrictions to an end. Taking into accouint the usual pace of such cases, this finding might reasonably be expected while the restrictions are in their second year.

This case began on 13 June 2017 when the USITC initiated a safeguard investigation of large residential washers. This investigation came in response to a petition filed by the Whirlpool Corporation. The commission determined that this investigation is “extraordinarily complicated,” and would make its injury determination by October 5, 2017.

On 21 November 2017, the commission announced the remedy recommendations that it will forward to the president. The Commissioners unanimously recommend a tariff-rate quota (TRQ) on imports of large residential washers for a duration of three years.  For U.S. imports of large residential washers that exceed 1.2 million units, the Commissioners recommend a tariff rate of 50 percent ad valorem, in addition to the current rate of duty.  They recommend that the in-quota volume remain constant throughout and that the above-quota tariff rate decrease by five percentage points during each year of the remedy period.  Chairman Schmidtlein and Commissioner Williamson additionally recommend an in-quota tariff rate of 20 percent ad valorem, which would decrease to 18 percent in the second year of the remedy period and 15 percent in the third year of the period, in addition to the current rate of duty.  Vice Chairman Johanson and Commissioner Broadbent do not recommend an in-quota tariff rate for large residential washers.

On 15 February 2019, the United States International Trade Commission announced the initiation of a review of the definitive duty imposed on imports of the subject good. 

On 21 January 2021, the US President issued a proclamation extending the safeguard measure imposed on imports of large residential washing machines following the conclusion of the review. The tariff rate quota is maintained with an in-quota volume level of 1.2 million units, an in-quota tariff rate of 15% in the fourth year, decreasing to 14% in the fifth year, and an above-quota tariff rate of 35% in the fourth year, decreasing to 30% in the fifth year. The proclamation extending the safeguard measure for two years entered into force on 8 February 2021.

sample_results.state_act_title: United States of America: Safeguard measure on imports of crystalline silicon photovoltaic cells

intervention_description.text:
On 17 May 2017, the United States International Trade Commission initiated a safeguard investigation on imports of certain crystalline silicon photovoltaic (CSPV) cells, whether or not partially or fully assembled into other products (including, but not limited to, modules, laminates, panels, and building-integrated materials) (‘‘CSPV products’’). The products subject to investigation are classified under HS code subheading 8541.40.60, 8501.31.80, 8501.61.00, 8507.20.80, 8501.61.00, 8507.20.80, 8501.31.80. This investigation follows the application lodged by Suniva Inc.

On 7 February 2018, the United States authorities imposed a safeguard measure on imports of the subject good. The measure was imposed in the form of (a) a tariff-rate quota on imports of solar cells not partially or fully assembled into other products and (b) an increase in duties on imports of modules. The tariff quota on imports of CSPV modules and CSPV cells in excess of 2.5 gigawatts (“GW”) annually consists of additional tariffs of 30% in the first year, 25% in the second year, 20% in the third year, and 15% in the fourth year. The US Presidential proclamation imposing the safeguard measure was published on 25 January 2018.

On 10 August 2021, the United States International Trade Commission announced the initiation of a review of the definitive duty imposed on imports of the subject good. This follows the application lodged on 2 and 4 August by Auxin Solar Inc., Suniva Inc., Hanwha Q CELLS USA, Inc, LG Electronics USA, Inc., and Mission Solar Energy. 

On 7 February 2022, the United States authorities extended the definitive safeguard duty on imports of the subject good, as follows: 

-       Extend the action for an additional four years, or until 7 February 2026, maintaining the TRQ on imports of CSPV cells with an increased in-quota volume level of 5.0 gigawatts, and continuing to phase down the action by decreasing the ad valorem tariff on out of-quota imports by 0.25 percentage points ad valorem from the rate in effect at the end of the fourth year of the measure on 6 February, 2022, continuing to decrease the ad valorem out-of-quota tariff by 0.25 percentage points in each succeeding year until the termination of the measure on 6 February 2026, and no additional tariff within the in-quota quantity of the tariff rate quota (TRQ).

-       With respect to CSPV modules, continue to phase down the action by decreasing the ad valorem tariff rate by 0.25 percentage points from the rate in effect at the end of the fourth year of the measure on 6 February 2022, and continuing to decrease the ad valorem rate by 0.25 percentage points in each succeeding year of the measure.

On 20 July 2022, the US authorities suspended the definitive safeguard duty imposed on imports of crystalline silicon photovoltaic cells from Canada, following an agreement reached between the US and Canada.

sample_results.state_act_title: Indonesia: Government established several restrictions on shipping and port companies

intervention_description.text:
On 28 October 2024, the government of Indonesia issued Law No. 66/2024, increasing the local content requirement for Indonesian-foreign shipping joint ventures (Shipping JVs) to get a permit to operate in Indonesia. Prior to this regulation. Shipping JVs are required to own at least one Indonesian-flagged vessel with a minimum measurement of 5'000 gross tonnage (GT). With the new regulation, Shipping JVs must now own and operate an Indonesian-flagged vessel with a minimum measurement of 50'000 GT per vessel.

According to the law, the stated objective is to reduce the cost of logistics as well as to promote national resilience. 

The regulation entered into force on 28 October 2024.

prompt: What FDI screening measures target Chinese investments in European technology sectors?

sample_results.state_act_title: EU: Commission publishes its new approach to economic security

intervention_description.text:
On 3 December 2025, the European Union published a Joint Communication outlining an approach to safeguarding the bloc’s economic security. The communication identifies six high-risk areas and proposes measures to balance openness with the need to avoid deepening or creating new dependencies. Among others, the Commission calls for measures strengthening the FDI review mechanisms in the EU.

Specifically, the Commission calls for "putting in place on a pilot basis an EU-level start-up monitoring mechanism aimed at identifying startups in critical technology areas that are vulnerable to the risk of hostile foreign acquisitions, redirecting them to EU investment alternatives and other forms of support (e.g., advisory, capacity-building, matchmaking with investors)." The Commission will also “work with supervisory authorities to monitor portfolio investments (…) in areas identified as high-risk.”

In addition, the Commission calls for the development of “guidelines drawing on the experience of implementing the current FDI Screening Regulation to ensure national screening authorities approach screening consistently, including in strategic sectors.” These guidelines “would also set out how to take account of the potential cumulative risk of multiple investments,” and would be complemented by guidance on the “interplay between any EU level requirements and the application of national screening mechanisms in the financial sector.” For other measures specified in the Joint Communication, see related interventions.

In this context, Stéphane Séjourné, Executive Vice-President for Prosperity and Industrial Strategy, noted: "In a more volatile and unpredictable world, Europe must update its strategic reflexes and prepare for every possible scenario. Our ability to safeguard the resilience of our economy cannot depend on any single geopolitical configuration. With the launch of the ResourceEU programme, this new doctrine is not just a vision for the future — it is already operational. We are equipping the Union with the tools it needs to remain strong, adaptable, and sovereign in the face of global uncertainty."

sample_results.state_act_title: United States of America: Presidential order that Beijing Shiji Information Technology Co., Ltd. divest StayNTouch, Inc

intervention_description.text:
On March 10, 2020 the Federal Register published a document signed on March 6, 2020 by which President Trump ordered the divestiture of the U.S. firm StayNTouch, Inc. by the Chinese firm Beijing Shiji Information Technology Co., Ltd. Invoking authority vested in him by the Constitution and section 721 of the Defense Production Act of 1950, the president stated that there was “credible evidence” leading him to believe that the proposed acquisition “threatens to impair the national security of the United States.” He therefore ordered that “the acquisition of StayNTouch by the Purchaser is hereby prohibited, and ownership by the Purchaser of any interest in StayNTouch and its assets, whether effected directly or indirectly through the Purchaser, or through the Purchaser's shareholders, partners, subsidiaries, or affiliates, is also prohibited.” The purchaser was also order to “divest all interests” in StayNTouch and that firm's “assets, intellectual property, technology, data (including customer data managed and stored by StayNTouch), personnel, and customer contracts” as well as “ any operations developed, held, or controlled, whether directly or indirectly, by StayNTouch at the time of, or since, its acquisition.”

StayNTouch describes itself as a “mobile hotel property management system (PMS) company focused on developing solutions that help hotels raise service levels, drive revenues, reduce costs, and ultimately change the way hotels can captivate their guests.” According to the company, its “game-changing solution frees hotels from the constraints of legacy or premise systems, dramatically streamlines operations, increases margins, and revolutionizes how front-line staff connects with guests.” The firm was founded in 2013, and was acquired by Shiji Group in September, 2018.

state_act_source.text: https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2020/03/10/2020-05011/regarding-the-acquisition-of-stayntouch-inc-by-beijing-shiji-information-technology-co-ltd

sample_results.state_act_title: United States of America: Executive Order on Securing the Information and Communications Technology and Services Supply Chain

intervention_description.text:
Among the consequences of being named under this procedure would be a prohibition on the company's acquisition of any U.S. firm.

On 19 January 2021, the U.S. Department of Commerce promulgated the interim final rule to implement the provision of Executive Order 13873. These regulations create the processes and procedures that the Secretary of Commerce will use to identify, assess, and address certain transactions in the area of information and communications technology or services (ICTS) between U.S. persons and foreign adversaries. These regulations allow the Commerce Secretary broad discretion to block or mitigate ICTS transactions involving a foreign adversary if the Commerce Secretary deems that transaction poses an unacceptable risk. The rule lists six foreign governments or non-government persons as foreign adversaries. These are the People's Republic of China, including the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (China); Cuba; the Islamic Republic of Iran; North Korea; the Russian Federation, and the Venezuelan president Nicolás Maduro.

This interim final rule will become effective on March 22, 2021.

state_act_source.text:
U.S. White House, Presidential Actions, Executive Orders, “Executive Order on Securing the Information and Communications Technology and Services Supply Chain”. Available at: https://trumpwhitehouse.archives.gov/presidential-actions/executive-order-securing-information-communications-technology-services-supply-chain/

U.S. Federal Register, 22689, Vol. 84, No.96, Presidential Documents, Executive Order 13873 of May 15, 2019, “Securing the Information and Communications Technology and Services Supply Chain”. Available at: https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/FR-2019-05-17/pdf/2019-10538.pdf

sample_results.state_act_title: Italy: EUR 390 million rescue loan to Acciaierie d'Italia

intervention_description.text:
On 9 February 2026, the European Commission approved a EUR 390 million (USD 463.5 million) rescue loan from Italy. The measure will support Acciaierie d'Italia (AdI) to meet its liquidity needs and cover standard operating costs such as wages and supplier payments. AdI is an Italian integrated steel producer with eight different production and servicing sites.

Specifically, the funding addresses the company's projected liquidity shortfall and ensures the continuity of its operations during an ongoing insolvency process that began in 2024 (see related state acts). This support is intended to bridge the financial gap until the business is transferred to a new operator following a tender process. The loan is granted at market rates for a duration of six months, after which Italy must submit a restructuring or liquidation plan or demonstrate that the loan has been repaid.

The Commission approved the rescue loan after assessing it under Article 107(3)(c) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU).

As of February 2026, the European Commission has not published its decision.

state_act_source.text: European Commission (9 February 2026). Commission approves €390 million Italian rescue loan to Acciaierie d'Italia under EU State aid rules (Retrieved on 10 February 2026): https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_26_328

sample_results.state_act_title: Germany: EUR 3 billion state aid scheme for cleantech manufacturing capacity

intervention_description.text:
On 5 February 2026, the European Commission approved a EUR 3 billion (USD 3.5 billion) state aid scheme from Germany. The measure will support investments that add manufacturing capacity for net-zero technologies and their components. The aid will take the form, among others, of direct grants. The scheme will be valid until 31 December 2030.

Specifically, eligible investment include net-zero technologies and their main specific components listed in Annexe II of the CISAF, secondary raw materials and the production of new or recovered related critical raw materials necessary for the production of those final products or main specific components. Some examples of eligible products are batteries, solar panels, wind turbines, heat-pumps, electrolysers, and carbon capture, usage and storage, including main specific components. The aid will also take the form of interest subsidies for loans, guarantees and tax advantages (see related interventions).

In this context, Teresa Ribera, Executive Vice-President for Clean, Just and Competitive Transition, said: "This scheme will ensure additional clean technology manufacturing capacity in Germany. The German state can provide EUR 3 billion in support for key investments in the sector".

As of February 2026, the European Commission has not published its decision.

The state aid is approved under the Clean Industrial Deal state aid framework (CISAF) of June 2025. The framework allows Member States to provide financial support for the development of clean energy and technology, as well as industrial decarbonisation (see related state act).

state_act_source.text: European Commission (5 February 2026). Commission approves EUR 3 billion German State aid scheme to support cleantech manufacturing capacity, contributing to Clean Industrial Deal objectives. Press release (Retrieved on 5 February 2026): https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_26_322

sample_results.state_act_title: India: Extension of definitive antidumping duty on imports of toluene diisocyanate from the EU and Saudi Arabia (definitive antidumping duty expired on imports from Chinese Taipei and the UAE)

intervention_description.text:
On 31 January 2020, the Indian authorities initiated an antidumping investigation on imports of toluene diisocyanate from the European Union and Saudi Arabia, as well as from Chinese Taipei, and the United Arab Emirates (please see the related intervention). The products subject to investigation are classified under HS code subheading 2929.10.20. The investigation follows the applications lodged by Gujarat Narmada Valley Fertilizers & Chemicals Limited.

On 27 April 2021, the Indian authorities imposed a definitive antidumping on imports of toluene diisocyanate from the European Union and Saudi Arabia. The rate of duty on imports from the European Union ranges from USD 102.05 per MT to USD 264.96 per MT depending on the company. The rate of duty on imports from Saudi Arabia ranges from USD 217.55 per MT to USD 344.33 per MT depending on the company.

On 30 December 2024, the Indian authorities announced the initiation of a sunset review of the definitive duty imposed on imports of the subject good from the European Union and Saudi Arabia. This follows the application lodged by Gujarat Nmmada Valley Fertilizers & Chemicals Limited.

On 20 August 2025, the Indian authorities extended the definitive duty on imports of the subject good from the European Union and Saudi Arabia until 1 March 2026 following the initiation of the sunset review.

On 10 February 2026, the Indian authorities extended the definitive duty imposed on imports of the subject good from the European Union and Saudi Arabia following the conclusion of the sunset review. The rate of duty remains unchanged. The definitive duty is in force for a period of five years.

sample_results.state_act_title: China: Definitive anti-subsidy duty on imports of certain dairy products from the European Union

intervention_description.text: On 21 August 2024, the Chinese authorities initiated an anti-subsidy investigation on imports of certain dairy products from the European Union. The products subject to investigation are classified under HS code subheadings 0401.50.00, 0406.10.00, 0406.20.00, 0406.30.00, 0406.40.00, and 0406.90.00. This investigation follows the application lodged on 29 July 2024 by the Dairy Association of China on behalf of the Chinese industry.

On 22 December 2025, the Chinese authorities imposed a provisional anti-subsidy duty on imports of the subject good from the European Union. The rate of duty on imports from the European Union ranges from 21.9% to 42.7%, depending on the company. The applicable duty imposition date is 23 December 2025.

On 12 February 2026, the Chinese authorities published a notice imposing a definitive anti-subsidy duty on imports of the subject good from the European Union. The rate of duty on imports from the European Union ranges from 7.4% to 11.7% depending on the company. The applicable duty imposition date is 13 February 2026. The definitive duty is in force for a period of five years.

sample_results.state_act_title: Canada: Tariff-rate quotas on imports of steel mill products from non-FTA partners

intervention_description.text:
On 27 June 2025, the government of Canada issued the Order Imposing a Surtax on the Importation of Certain Steel Goods, imposing a new tariff rate quotas (TRQs) for steel mill products imported into Canada from non-free trade agreement (FTA) partners. The total TRQ is set at 2.6 million tonnes. The out-of-quota tariff will amount to a 50% surtax on steel imports above 2024 levels from non-FTA partners. The quotas enter into force on 27 June 2025 and is effective for one year.

The quotas would apply as follows:

  1. Quarterly total of 186'856 tonnes for "flat" steel products. The category contains products under HS headings 7208, 7209, 7210, 7211, 7212, 7225, 7226. The surtaxes are to apply to imports from a certain country only if these imports exceed 36% of the total quota.1. Quarterly total of 178'512 tonnes for "long" steel products. The category contains products under HS headings 7213, 7214, 7216, 7217, 7224, 7227, 7228, 7229, 7301. The surtaxes are to apply to imports from a certain country only if these imports exceed 28% of the total quota.1. Quarterly total of 117'406 tonnes for "pipe and tube" steel products. The category contains products under HS headings 7304, 7405, 7306. The surtaxes are to apply to imports from a certain country only if these imports exceed 47% of the total quota.1. Quarterly total of 152'383 tonnes for "semi-finished" steel products. The category contains products under HS headings 7206, 7207, 7224. The surtaxes are to apply to imports from a certain country only if these imports exceed 72% of the total quota.1. Quarterly total of 15'568 tonnes for "stainless" steel products. The category contains products under HS headings 7218, 7222, 7304. The surtaxes are to apply to imports from a certain country only if these imports exceed 91% of the total quota.This surtax would be imposed in addition to any current surtaxes, anti-dumping duties, and countervailing measures, plus any future tariff measures determined by the country where steel is melted and poured.

The quotas will be reviewed in 30 days from the measure's inception "to ensure their appropriateness and effectiveness in light of evolving market circumstances, including progress in the broader trading arrangement with the United States, and periodically thereafter".

In the press release, the government highlighted that the TRQ is intended to "help stabilise the Canadian steel market by addressing the risk that steel originally destined for the United States is redirected to Canada".

In this context, François-Philippe Champagne, Minister of Finance and National Revenue, said:  “Our government has a mandate to build one Canadian economy—the strongest in the G7. That means standing up for our industries and workers and defending them from the harmful impacts of unjust U.S. tariffs".

On 30 July 2025, the government of Canada issued Order Amending the Order Imposing a Surtax on the Importation of Certain Steel Goods: SOR/2025-155. The Order reduces the size of TRQ on non-FTA partners from 100% of 2024 levels to 50%. The measures enters into force on 1 August 2025.
